docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (BET) BET HIP-HOP AWARDS 2007 T. I. never made it to this second annual ceremony, taped on Saturday at the Atlanta Civic Center and created to pay tribute to hip-hop's style, substance and swagger, in the words of BET. He was arrested on federal weapons charges -- he's accused of trying to buy three machine guns and two silencers -- just hours before his scheduled performance on the show, which honored him with two awards nonetheless. Among the other nominees were 50 Cent, above right, Mary J. Blige, center, Ludacris, Jay-Z, Nas, Diddy, Keyshia Cole, Birdman and DJ Drama in categories like best hip-hop collabo, best ringtone and hustler of the year. Ludacris, Soulja Boy, Kanye West, Nelly, Lil Wayne and Common, above left, performed; Wyclef Jean, Cassidy, Lil Mama, Ras Kass and Status Quo got props for just showing up. And KRS-One was honored with the ''I Am Hip-Hop'' Icon Award. 8 P.M. (22, 26) WIRED SCIENCE Just in time for the World Series, this spinoff of Wired magazine explores the baseballs used in Major League games, and the mechanical engineers who make sure that each one has the correct degree of hardness and bounce.

docs.lead_paragraph: George W. Thorn, a physician whose work helped transform the treatment of kidney diseases and other disorders, notably Addison's disease, died June 26 at an assisted living center in Beverly, Mass., said his son, Weston. He was 98. Dr. Thorn was physician in chief at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston, a forerunner of Brigham and Women's Hospital, from 1942 to 1972. He was known for his groundbreaking work on the diagnosis and treatment of Addison's disease, the debilitating disorder caused by failure in the adrenal glands that afflicted President John F. Kennedy.
docs.abstract: Dr George W Thorn, physician whose work helped transform treatment of kidney diseases and other disorders, notably Addison's disease, dies at age 98; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AstraZeneca, working with genome pioneer Craig Venter, is launching a massive gene hunt in the most comprehensive bet yet by a pharmaceutical firm on the potential of genetic variations to unlock routes to new medicines.

docs.lead_paragraph: When I.B.M.'s Watson computer beat two human "Jeopardy!" champions earlier this year, it was a triumphant demonstration of the company's technology. It was great for Big Blue's image, but it was not a moneymaker on its own.
docs.abstract: The ingredients that went into I.B.M.'s "Jeopardy!"-winning computer Watson are steadily finding their way into I.B.M. products. The latest entry is being announced on Thursday, a so-called insight platform, which scours millions patents and scientific journals for insights and trends in drug development and discovery.

docs.abstract: Google Now raises questions about the line between when tech is helpful and when it makes users uneasy. The service will do things like remind an Android owner that they have a lunch date — but also who it is with, how to get there and when they should leave, based on traffic.

docs.lead_paragraph: Though Web search is dominated by Google and supplemented by link-sharing on Facebook and Twitter, a start-up, Trapit, which opens to the public Tuesday, thinks it can offer a smarter, more personalized way to search for topics.
docs.abstract: Trapit, a start-up that opens to the public Tuesday, offers a new way to search the Web for topics by using machine learning. It is trying to provide an alternative to Google's search engine and link sharing on Facebook and Twitter.

headline.main: A Start-Up Offers a New Way to Search the Web
